SPEAR: Exact Gradient Inversion of Batches in Federated Learning

Â 

Dimitar I. Dimitrovâ€‰1â€‰ Maximilian Baaderâ€‰1â€‰ Mark Niklas MÃ¼llerâ€‰1â€‰ Martin Vechevâ€‰1â€‰


â€ â€ footnotetext: 1Department of Computer Science, ETH Zurich, Zurich, Switzerland. Correspondence to: Dimitar I. Dimitrov <dimitadi@inf.ethz.ch>. Â 
Abstract

Federated learning is a popular framework for collaborative machine learning where multiple clients only share gradient updates on their local data with the server and not the actual data. Unfortunately, it was recently shown that gradient inversion attacks can reconstruct this data from these shared gradients. Existing attacks enable exact reconstruction only for a batch size of b=1ğ‘1b=1 in the important honest-but-curious setting, with larger batches permitting only approximate reconstruction. In this work, we propose the first algorithm reconstructing whole batches with b>1ğ‘1b>1 exactly. This approach combines mathematical insights into the explicit low-rank structure of gradients with a sampling-based algorithm. Crucially, we leverage ReLU-induced gradient sparsity to precisely filter out large numbers of incorrect samples, making a final reconstruction step tractable. We provide an efficient GPU implementation for fully connected networks and show that it recovers batches of bâ‰²25less-than-or-similar-toğ‘25b\lesssim 25 elements exactly while being tractable for large network widths and depths.

1 Introduction

Federated learning

has emerged as the dominant paradigm for training machine learning models collaboratively without sharing sensitive data (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). Instead, a central server sends the current model to all clients which then compute gradients with their private data and send them back to the server. There, the gradients are aggregated and used to update the model. Using this approach sensitive data never leaves the clientsâ€™ machines, aligning it better with data privacy regulations such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA).

Gradient Inversion Attacks

Recent work has shown that an honest-but-curious server can use the shared gradient updates to reconstruct the sensitive client data (Zhu etÂ al., 2019; Dimitrov etÂ al., 2022). However, while exact reconstruction was shown to be possible for batch sizes of b=1ğ‘1b=1 (Phong etÂ al., 2018; Zhu & Blaschko, 2021), it was assumed to be infeasible for larger batches. This led to a line of research on approximate methods that sacrificed reconstruction quality in order to recover batches of b>1ğ‘1b>1 inputs Geng etÂ al. (2021); Vero etÂ al. (2022); Kariyappa etÂ al. (2023). In this paper we challenge this fundamental assumption and, for the first time, show that exact reconstruction is possible for batch sizes b>1ğ‘1b>1.

This Work: Exact Reconstruction of Batches

We propose the first gradient inversion attack reconstructing inputs exactly for batch sizes b>1ğ‘1b>1 in the honest-but-curious setting. We illustrate the resulting reconstruction quality in FigureÂ 1, comparing it to approximate reconstructions for a batch of b=20ğ‘20b=20 images (Geiping etÂ al., 2020).

Our approach leverages two key properties of gradient updates in fully connected ReLU networks: First, these gradients have a specific low-rank structure due to small batch sizes bâ‰ªn,mmuch-less-thanğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘šb\ll n,m compared to the input dimensionality nğ‘›n and the hidden dimension mğ‘šm. Second, the (unknown) gradients with respect to the inputs of the first ReLU layer are sparse due to the ReLU function itself. We now combine these properties with ideas from sparsely-used dictionary learning Spielman etÂ al. (2012) to propose a sampling-based algorithm, called SPEAR (Sparsity Exploiting Activation Recovery) and show that it succeeds with high probability for b<mğ‘ğ‘šb<m. While SPEAR scales exponentially with batch size bğ‘b, we provide a highly parallelized GPU implementation of SPEAR, which empirically allows us to reconstruct batches of size up to bâ‰²25less-than-or-similar-toğ‘25b\lesssim 25 exactly even for large inputs (TinyImageNet) and networks (widths up to 200020002000 and depths up to 999) in around one minute.

Main Contributions:

  • â€¢

    The first method to exactly reconstruct complete batches of size b>1ğ‘1b\!>\!1 in the honest-but-curious setting.

  • â€¢

    SPEAR: an algorithm that leverages low rankness and ReLU-induced sparsity of gradients in a highly parallelizable sampling-based algorithm for exact gradient inversion that succeeds with high probability.

  • â€¢

    A highly parallelized GPU implementation of SPEAR, which we empirically demonstrate to be effective across a wide range of settings.

3 Gradient Inversion via Sparsity and Low-Rankness

In this Section, we will demonstrate that both low rankness and sparsity arise naturally for gradients of fully connected ReLU networks and explain theoretically how we recover ğ‘¿ğ‘¿{\bm{X}}. The remainder of our approach then focuses on recovering ğ‘¸ğ‘¸{\bm{Q}}. To this end, we show in SectionÂ 3.2 that ReLU layers induce sparsity in âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’â„’ğ’\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}, which we then leveraged in SectionÂ 3.3 to reconstruct the columns of ğ‘¸ğ‘¸{\bm{Q}} up to scale. Finally, in SectionÂ 3.4, we show how the scale of ğ‘¸ğ‘¸{\bm{Q}}â€™s columns can be recovered from âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’ƒâ„’ğ’ƒ\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{b}}}. Unless otherwise noted, we defer all proofs to App.Â A.

3.2 ReLU-Induced Sparsity

ReLU activation layers can induce sparsity both in the gradient âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’â„’ğ’\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} (if the ReLU activation succeeds the considered linear layer) or in the input (if the ReLU activation precedes the considered linear layer).

Gradien Sparsity

If a ReLU activation succeeds the linear layer, i.e., ğ’€=ReLUâ¡(ğ’)ğ’€ReLUğ’{\bm{Y}}=\operatorname{ReLU}({\bm{Z}}), we have:

âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’=âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’€âŠ™ğŸ™[ğ’>0],â„’ğ’direct-productâ„’ğ’€subscript1delimited-[]ğ’0\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Y}}}\odot\mathds{1}_{[{\bm{Z}}>0]}, (4)

where âŠ™direct-product\odot is the elementwise multiplication and ğŸ™[ğ’>0]subscript1delimited-[]ğ’0\mathds{1}_{[{\bm{Z}}>0]} is a matrix of 00s and 111s with each entry indicating if the corresponding entry in ğ’ğ’{\bm{Z}} is positive. At initialization, roughly half of the entries in ğ’ğ’{\bm{Z}} are positive, making âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’â„’ğ’\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} sparse with roughly half the entries being 00.

Input Sparsity

ReLU activations also introduce sparsity if the linear layer in question is preceded by a ReLU activation layer. In this case, ğ‘¿=ReLUâ¡(ğ’~)ğ‘¿ReLU~ğ’{\bm{X}}=\operatorname{ReLU}(\tilde{{\bm{Z}}}) will be sparse with roughly half of its entries being 00s at initialization.

Note that for all but the first and the last layer of a fully connected network, we have sparsity in both, ğ‘¿ğ‘¿{\bm{X}} and âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’â„’ğ’\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}. Due to the symmetry of EquationsÂ 2 andÂ 3, our method can be applied in all three arising sparsity settings. In the remainder of this work, we assume w.l.o.g. that only âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’â„’ğ’\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} is sparse, corresponding to the first layer of a fully connected network. We now describe how to leverage this sparsity to compute the disaggregation matrix ğ‘¸ğ‘¸{\bm{Q}} and thus recover the input batch ğ‘¿ğ‘¿{\bm{X}}.

3.3 Breaking Aggregation through Sparsity

Our exact recovery algorithm for the disaggregation matrix ğ‘¸ğ‘¸{\bm{Q}} is based on the following insight:

If we can construct two submatrices ğ‘¨âˆˆâ„bâˆ’1Ã—bğ‘¨superscriptâ„ğ‘1ğ‘{\bm{A}}\in\mathbb{R}^{b-1\times b} and ğ‘³Aâˆˆâ„bâˆ’1Ã—bsubscriptğ‘³ğ´superscriptâ„ğ‘1ğ‘{\bm{L}}_{A}\in\mathbb{R}^{b-1\times b} by choosing bâˆ’1ğ‘1b-1 rows with the same indices from âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’â„’ğ’\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} and ğ‘³ğ‘³{\bm{L}}, respectively, such that ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bm{A}} has full rank and an all-zero ithsuperscriptğ‘–thi^{\text{th}} column, then the kernel kerâ¡(ğ‘³ğ‘¨)kernelsubscriptğ‘³ğ‘¨\ker({\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}}) of ğ‘³ğ‘¨subscriptğ‘³ğ‘¨{\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}} contains a column ğ’’isubscriptğ’’ğ‘–{\bm{q}}_{i} of ğ‘¸ğ‘¸{\bm{Q}} up to scale. We formalize this as follows:

Theorem 3.4.

4 Efficient Filtering and Validation of Candidates

In the previous section, we saw that given the correct selection of submatrices ğ‘³ğ‘¨subscriptğ‘³ğ‘¨{\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}}, we can recover ğ‘¸ğ‘¸{\bm{Q}} directly. However, we do not know how to pick ğ‘³ğ‘¨subscriptğ‘³ğ‘¨{\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}} a priori. To solve this problem, we rely on a sampling-based approach: We first randomly sample submatrices ğ‘³ğ‘¨subscriptğ‘³ğ‘¨{\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}} of ğ‘³ğ‘³{\bm{L}} and corresponding direction candidates ğ’’Â¯â€²superscriptÂ¯ğ’’â€²\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime} spanning kerâ¡(ğ‘³ğ‘¨)kernelsubscriptğ‘³ğ‘¨\ker({\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}}). However, checking whether ğ’’Â¯â€²superscriptÂ¯ğ’’â€²\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime} is a valid direction is not straightforward as we do not know âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’â„’ğ’\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} and hence can not observe ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bm{A}} directly as reconstructing âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’=ğ‘³â€‹ğ‘¸â„’ğ’ğ‘³ğ‘¸\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}={\bm{L}}{\bm{Q}} requires the full ğ‘¸ğ‘¸{\bm{Q}}.

To address this, we propose a method to filter the majority of wrong proposals ğ’’Â¯â€²superscriptÂ¯ğ’’â€²\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime} using deduplication and a sparsity-based criterion (discussed in SectionÂ 4.1). This leaves us with a set of candidate directions ğ’={ğ’’Â¯jâ€²}jâˆˆ{1,â€¦,c}ğ’subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ’’ğ‘—â€²ğ‘—1â€¦ğ‘\mathcal{C}=\{\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{j}^{\prime}\}_{j\in\{1,\dots,c\}}, among which we then select the correct directions by greedily optimizing a novel sparsity matching score (discussed in SectionÂ 4.2).

4.1 Efficient Filtering of Directions ğ’’Â¯â€²superscriptÂ¯ğ’’â€²\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime}

Filtering Mixtures via Sparsity

It is highly likely (p=(1âˆ’12bâˆ’1)bğ‘superscript11superscript2ğ‘1ğ‘p=(1-\tfrac{1}{2^{b-1}})^{b}) that a random submatrix of ğ‘³ğ‘³{\bm{L}} will not correspond to an ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bm{A}} with any ğŸ0\mathbf{0} column. We filter these directions by leveraging the following insight. The kernel of such submatrices is spanned by a linear combination ğ’’Â¯â€²=âˆ‘iÎ±iâ€‹ğ’’Â¯isuperscriptÂ¯ğ’’â€²subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–subscriptÂ¯ğ’’ğ‘–\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime}=\sum_{i}\alpha_{i}\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i}. Thus ğ‘³â€‹ğ’’Â¯â€²ğ‘³superscriptÂ¯ğ’’â€²{\bm{L}}\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime} will be a linear combination of sparse columns of âˆ‚ğ“›âˆ‚ğ’ğ“›ğ’\frac{\partial\mathcal{{\bm{L}}}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}. As this sparsity structure is random, linear combinations will have much lower sparsity with high probability. We thus discard all candidates ğ’’Â¯â€²superscriptÂ¯ğ’’â€²\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime} with sparsity of ğ‘³â€‹ğ’’Â¯â€²ğ‘³superscriptÂ¯ğ’’â€²{\bm{L}}\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime} below a threshold Ï„ğœ\tau, chosen to make the probability of falsely rejecting a correct direction pfâ€‹râ€‹(Ï„,m)=12mâ€‹âˆ‘i=0âŒŠmâ‹…Ï„âŒ‹(mi)subscriptğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘Ÿğœğ‘š1superscript2ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–0â‹…ğ‘šğœbinomialğ‘šğ‘–p_{fr}(\tau,m)=\frac{1}{2^{m}}\sum_{i=0}^{\lfloor m\cdot\tau\rfloor}\binom{m}{i}, obtained from the cumulative distribution function of the binomial distribution, small. For example for m=400ğ‘š400m=400 and pfâ€‹râ€‹(Ï„,m)<10âˆ’5subscriptğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘Ÿğœğ‘šsuperscript105p_{fr}(\tau,m)<10^{-5}, we have Ï„=0.395ğœ0.395\tau=0.395. We obtain the candidate pool ğ’={ğ’’Â¯jâ€²}jâˆˆ{1,â€¦,c}ğ’subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ’’ğ‘—â€²ğ‘—1â€¦ğ‘\mathcal{C}=\{\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{j}^{\prime}\}_{j\in\{1,\dots,c\}} from all samples that were not filered this way.

Filtering Duplicates

As it is highly likely to have multiple full-rank submatrices ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bm{A}}, whose ithsuperscriptğ‘–thi^{\text{th}} column is ğŸ0\mathbf{0}, we expect to sample the same proposal ğ’’Â¯iâ€²superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ’’ğ‘–â€²\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i}^{\prime} multiple times. We remove these duplicates substantially reduces our search space.

4.2 Greedy Optimization

While filtering duplicates and linear combinations significantly reduces the number cğ‘c of candidates, we usually still have to select a subset of b<cğ‘ğ‘b<c. Thus, we have (cb)binomialğ‘ğ‘\binom{c}{b} possible bğ‘b sized subsets, each inducing a candidate ğ‘¸â€²superscriptğ‘¸â€²{\bm{Q}}^{\prime} and thus ğ‘¿â€²superscriptğ‘¿â€²{\bm{X}}^{\prime}. A naive approach would be to compute the gradients for all ğ‘¿â€²superscriptğ‘¿â€²{\bm{X}}^{\prime} and compare them against the ground truth. However, this is computationally intractable even for moderate candidate numbers cğ‘c.

To address this, we propose a greedy two-stage procedure optimizing a novel sparsity matching score Ïƒğœ\sigma, solely relying on âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’â€²superscriptâ„’ğ’â€²\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}^{\prime} and ğ’â€²superscriptğ’â€²{\bm{Z}}^{\prime}. As both can be computed directly via ğ‘¸â€²superscriptğ‘¸â€²{\bm{Q}}^{\prime}, the procedure is local, does not need to backpropagate gradients and resolves the computational complexity issue mentioned at the beginning of this subsection while also accurately selecting the correct batch elements. Next, we explain the first stage.

Dictionary Learning (Spielman etÂ al., 2012)

As a first stage, we leverage a component of the algorithm proposed by Spielman etÂ al. (2012) for sparsely-used dictionary learning. This approach is based on the insight that the subset of column vectors {ğ’’Â¯iâ€²}i=1bsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ’’ğ‘–â€²ğ‘–1ğ‘\{\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i}^{\prime}\}_{i=1}^{b}, yielding the sparsest full-rank gradient matrix âˆ‚Lâˆ‚ğ’ğ¿ğ’\frac{\partial L}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} via EquationÂ 2 is often correct. As the scaling of ğ’’Â¯iâ€²superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ’’ğ‘–â€²\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i}^{\prime} does not change the sparsity in EquationÂ 2, we can construct this subset â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} by greedily collecting the bğ‘b directions ğ’’Â¯iâ€²superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ’’ğ‘–â€²\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i}^{\prime} with the highest corresponding sparsity that still increases the rank of â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B}. While this approach typically recovers most directions ğ’’Â¯isubscriptÂ¯ğ’’ğ‘–\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i}, it often misses directions whose gradients âˆ‚Lâˆ‚ğ’›iğ¿subscriptğ’›ğ‘–\frac{\partial L}{\partial{\bm{z}}_{i}} are less sparse by chance.

Sparsity Matching

We alleviate this issue by introducing a second stage to the algorithm where we greedily optimize a novel correctness measure based solely on the gradients of the linear layer, which we call the sparsity matching coefficient Ïƒğœ\sigma.

Definition 4.1.

Let Ïƒâˆ’subscriptğœ\sigma_{-} be the number of non-positive entries in ğ’ğ’{\bm{Z}} whose corresponding entries in âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’â„’ğ’\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} are 00. Similarly, let Ïƒ+subscriptğœ\sigma_{+} be the number of positive entries in ğ’ğ’{\bm{Z}} whose corresponding entries in âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’â„’ğ’\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} are not 00. We call their normalized sum the sparsity matching coefficient Ïƒğœ\sigma:

Ïƒ=Ïƒâˆ’+Ïƒ+mâ‹…b.ğœsubscriptğœsubscriptğœâ‹…ğ‘šğ‘\sigma=\frac{\sigma_{-}+\sigma_{+}}{m\cdot b}.

Intuitively, this describes how well the pre-activation values ğ’ğ’{\bm{Z}} match the sparsity pattern of the gradients âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’â„’ğ’\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}, induced by the succeeding ReLU layer ğ’€=ReLUâ¡(ğ’)ğ’€ReLUğ’{\bm{Y}}=\operatorname{ReLU}({\bm{Z}}), as shown in EquationÂ 4.

While this sparsity matching coefficient Ïƒğœ\sigma can take values between 00 and 111, it is exactly Ïƒ=1ğœ1\sigma=1 for the correct ğ‘¿ğ‘¿{\bm{X}}, if the gradient âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’€â„’ğ’€\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Y}}} w.r.t. the ReLU output is dense, which is usually the case. We note that Ïƒğœ\sigma can be computed efficiently for arbitrary full rank matrix ğ‘¸Â¯â€²superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¸â€²\overline{{\bm{Q}}}^{\prime} by computing âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’â€²=ğ‘³â€‹ğ‘¸â€²superscriptâ„’ğ’â€²ğ‘³superscriptğ‘¸â€²\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}^{\prime}={\bm{L}}{\bm{Q}}^{\prime} and ğ’â€²=ğ‘¾â€‹ğ‘¿â€²+(ğ’ƒâ€‹|â€¦|â€‹ğ’ƒ)superscriptğ’â€²ğ‘¾superscriptğ‘¿â€²ğ’ƒâ€¦ğ’ƒ{\bm{Z}}^{\prime}={\bm{W}}{\bm{X}}^{\prime}+({\bm{b}}|\dots|{\bm{b}}) for ğ‘¿â€²â£âŠ¤=ğ‘¸â€²â£âˆ’1â€‹ğ‘¹superscriptğ‘¿â€²topsuperscriptğ‘¸â€²1ğ‘¹{\bm{X}}^{\prime\top}={\bm{Q}}^{\prime-1}{\bm{R}}.

To optimize Ïƒğœ\sigma, we initialize ğ‘¸Â¯â€²superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¸â€²\overline{{\bm{Q}}}^{\prime} with the result of the greedy algorithm in Spielman etÂ al. (2012), and then greedily swap the pair of vectors ğ’’Â¯iâ€²subscriptsuperscriptÂ¯ğ’’â€²ğ‘–\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime}_{i} that improves Ïƒğœ\sigma the most, while not changing the rank, until convergence.

5 Final Algorithm and Complexity Analysis

In this section, we first present our final algorithm SPEAR (SectionÂ 5.1) and then analyse its expected complexity and failure probability (SectionÂ 5.2).

5.1 Final Algorithm

We formalize our gradient inversion attack SPEAR in AlgorithmÂ 1 and outline it below. First, we compute the low-rank decomposition âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ‘¾=ğ‘³â€‹ğ‘¹â„’ğ‘¾ğ‘³ğ‘¹\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{W}}}={\bm{L}}{\bm{R}} of the weight gradient âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ‘¾â„’ğ‘¾\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{W}}} via reduced SVD, allowing us to recover the batch size bğ‘b as the rank of âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ‘¾â„’ğ‘¾\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{W}}} (LineÂ 2). We now sample (at most Nğ‘N) submatrices ğ‘³ğ‘¨subscriptğ‘³ğ‘¨{\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}} of ğ‘³ğ‘³{\bm{L}} and compute proposal directions ğ’’Â¯iâ€²superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ’’ğ‘–â€²\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i}^{\prime} as their kernel kerâ¡(ğ‘³ğ‘¨)kernelsubscriptğ‘³ğ‘¨\ker({\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}}) via SVD (LinesÂ 4 andÂ 5). We note that our implementation parallelizes both sampling and SVD computation (LinesÂ 4 andÂ 5) on a GPU. We then filter the proposal directions ğ’’Â¯iâ€²superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ’’ğ‘–â€²\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i}^{\prime} based on their sparsity (LineÂ 6), adding them to our candidate pool ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} if they havenâ€™t been recovered already and are sufficiently sparse (LineÂ 7). Once our candidate pool contains at least bğ‘b directions, we begin constructing candidate input reconstructions ğ‘¿â€²superscriptğ‘¿â€²{\bm{X}}^{\prime} using our two-stage greedy algorithm GreedyFilter (LineÂ 8), discussed in SectionÂ 4.2. If this reconstruction leads to a solution with sparsity matching coefficient Ïƒ=1ğœ1\sigma=1, we terminate early and return the corresponding candidate solution (LineÂ 9). Otherwise, we continue sampling until we have reached Nğ‘N samples and return the best reconstruction we can obtain from the resulting candidate pool (LineÂ 11). The pseudocode for ComputeSigma (AlgorithmÂ 2) and GreedyFilter (AlgorithmÂ 3) are deferred to App.Â B.

5.2 Analysis

In this section, we will analyze SPEAR w.r.t. the number of submatrices we expect to sample until we have recovered all bğ‘b correct directions ğ’’Â¯isubscriptÂ¯ğ’’ğ‘–\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i} (LemmaÂ 5.2), and the probability of failing to recover all bğ‘b correct directions despite checking all possible submatrices of ğ‘³ğ‘³{\bm{L}} (LemmaÂ 5.3). For an analysis of the number of submatrices we have to sample until we have recovered all bğ‘b correct directions ğ’’Â¯isubscriptÂ¯ğ’’ğ‘–\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i} with high probability, we point to LemmaÂ A.1. Further, as before, we defer all proofs also to App.Â A.

Lemma 5.1.

We can now compute the expected number of submatrices ntotalâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘›totaln^{*}_{\text{total}} we have to draw until we have recovered all bğ‘b correct direction vectors using the Coupon Collector Problem:

Lemma 5.2.

Assuming i.i.d.Â submatrices ğ€ğ€{\bm{A}} following the distribution outlined in LemmaÂ 5.1 and using AlgorithmÂ 1, we have the expected number of submatrices ntotalâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘›totaln^{*}_{\text{total}} required to recover all bğ‘b correct direction vectors as:

ntotalâˆ—=1qâ€‹âˆ‘k=0bâˆ’1bbâˆ’k=bâ€‹Hbqâ‰ˆ1qâ€‹(bâ€‹logâ¡(b)+Î³â€‹b+12),subscriptsuperscriptğ‘›total1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ‘1ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘subscriptğ»ğ‘ğ‘1ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ›¾ğ‘12n^{*}_{\text{total}}=\frac{1}{q}\sum_{k=0}^{b-1}\frac{b}{b-k}=\frac{bH_{b}}{q}\approx\frac{1}{q}(b\log(b)+\gamma b+\tfrac{1}{2}),

where Hbsubscriptğ»ğ‘H_{b} is the bthsuperscriptğ‘thb^{\text{th}} harmonic number and Î³â‰ˆ0.57722ğ›¾0.57722\gamma\approx 0.57722 the Euler-Mascheroni constant.

We validate this result experimentally in FigureÂ 4 where we observe excellent agreement for wide networks (mâ‰«bmuch-greater-thanğ‘šğ‘m\gg b) and obtain, e.g., ntotalâˆ—â‰ˆ1.8Ã—105subscriptsuperscriptğ‘›total1.8superscript105n^{*}_{\text{total}}\approx 1.8\times 10^{5} for a batch size of b=16ğ‘16b=16.

Failure Probability

6 Empirical Evaluation

In this section, we empirically evaluate the effectiveness of SPEAR on MNIST (LeCun etÂ al., 2010), CIFAR-10 (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009), and TinyImageNet (Le & Yang, 2015) across a wide range of settings. In addition to the reconstruction quality metrics PSNR, SSIM, MSE, and LPIPS, commonly used to evaluate gradient inversion attacks, we report accuracy as the portion of batches for which we recovered all batch elements exactly (up to numerical errors) and the number of sampled submatrices (number of iterations).

Experimental Setup

For all reported experiments, we use our highly parallelized PyTorch-based (Paszke etÂ al., 2019) GPU implementation of SPEAR. Unless indicated otherwise, we run all of our experiments with a batch size of b=20ğ‘20b=20 CIFAR-10 images using a 666 layer fully-connected ReLU network with a width of m=200ğ‘š200m=200 and choose Ï„ğœ\tau to achieve a false rejection rate of pfâ€‹râ‰¤10âˆ’5subscriptğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘Ÿsuperscript105p_{fr}\leq 10^{-5}.

6.1 Main Results

We evaluate SPEAR on MNIST, CIFAR-10, and TinyImageNet, reporting results in TableÂ 1. Across datasets, SPEAR can reconstruct almost all batches perfectly, achieving PSNRs of 100100100 and above even at a batch size of b=20ğ‘20b=20. As these results indicate a significantly better reconstruction than any other method applicable to batch sizes b>1ğ‘1b>1, we omit a detailed quantitative comparison to prior work.

6.2 Ablation Studies

Effect of Batch Size bğ‘b

We evaluate the effect of batch size bğ‘b on accuracy and the required number of iterations ntotalâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘›totaln^{*}_{\text{total}} for a wide (m=2000ğ‘š2000m=2000) and narrow (m=200ğ‘š200m=200) network. While ntotalâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘›totaln^{*}_{\text{total}} increases exponentially with bğ‘b, for both networks, the narrower network requires about 202020 times more iterations than the wider network (see FigureÂ 4). While trends for the wider network (mâ‰«bmuch-greater-thanğ‘šğ‘m\gg b) are perfectly described by our theoretical results in SectionÂ 5.2, some independence assumptions are violated for the narrower network, explaining the larger number of required iterations. While we can recover all batches perfectly for the wider network, we see a sharp drop in accuracy from 99%percent9999\% at b=20ğ‘20b=20 to 63%percent6363\% at b=24ğ‘24b=24 (see FigureÂ 6) for the narrower network. This is due to increasingly more batches requiring more than the N=2Ã—109ğ‘2superscript109N=2\times 10^{9} submatrices we sample at most.

Effect of Network Architecture

We visualize the performance of SPEAR across different network widths and depths in FigureÂ 5. We observe that while accuracy is independent of both (given sufficient width mâ‰«bmuch-greater-thanğ‘šğ‘m\gg b), the number of required iterations reduces with increasing width mğ‘šm.

Effectivness of our 2-Stage Greedy Algorithm

We compare reconstruction success rate (accuracy) with and without the second stage of our greedy algorithm discussed in SectionÂ 4.2 in FigureÂ 6. We observe that this second stage becomes increasingly important for larger batch size bğ‘b.

Effect of Network Training

We train a network on MNIST and evaluate SPEAR periodically during training, visualizing results in FigureÂ 7. We observe that generally SPEAR performs very well on trained networks, with the number of required steps as on untrained networks. However, if the minimum column sparsity of âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’â„’ğ’\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} drops significantly as is the case for the checkpoints after 2000 and 3000 steps in the illustrated run performance drops slightly.

Failure Probabilities

We validate our theoretical results on SPEARâ€™s failure rate (LemmaÂ 5.3) in FigureÂ 8. As this requires exhaustive sampling of all (mbâˆ’1)binomialğ‘šğ‘1\binom{m}{b-1} submatrices of ğ‘³ğ‘³{\bm{L}} we only consider small batch sizes bâ‰¤10ğ‘10b\leq 10 and networks mâ‰¤40ğ‘š40m\leq 40. We observe that the empirical failure probability (blue) with 95%percent9595\% Clopper-Pearson confidence bounds lies between the analytical upper bound (dashed line) and approximation (solid line). We conclude that in most settings, the number of required samples rather than complete failure is the limiting factor for SPEARâ€™s performance.

7 Related Work

In this section, we discuss how we relate to prior work.

Gradient Inversion Attacks

Since gradient inversion attacks have been introduced (Zhu etÂ al., 2019), two settings have emerged: In the malicious setting, the server does not adhere to the training protocol and can adversarially engineer network weights that maximize leaked information (Boenisch etÂ al., 2021; Fowl etÂ al., 2022b; a; Wen etÂ al., 2022). In the strictly harder honest-but-curious setting, the server follows the training protocol but still aims to reconstruct client data. We target the honest-but-curious setting, where prior work has either recovered the input exactly for batch sizes of b=1ğ‘1b=1 (Phong etÂ al., 2018; Zhu & Blaschko, 2021), or approximately for b>1ğ‘1b>1 Geiping etÂ al. (2020); Yin etÂ al. (2021); Geng etÂ al. (2021); Vero etÂ al. (2022); Kariyappa etÂ al. (2023). In this setting, we are the first to reconstruct inputs exactly for batch sizes b>1ğ‘1b>1.

Most closely related to our work is Kariyappa etÂ al. (2023) which leverage the low-rank structure of the gradients to frame gradient inversion as a blind source separation problem, improving their approximate reconstructions. In contrast, we derive an explicit low-rank representation and additionally leverage gradient sparsity reconstruct inputs exactly.

Unlike a long line of prior work, we rely neither on any priors on the data distribution (Vero etÂ al., 2022; BalunoviÄ‡ etÂ al., 2022a; Gupta etÂ al., 2022; Li etÂ al., 2022) nor on a reconstructed classification label Geiping etÂ al. (2020); Zhao etÂ al. (2020); Geng etÂ al. (2021); Yin etÂ al. (2021); Vero etÂ al. (2022). This allows our approach to be employed in a much wider range of settings where neither is available.

Defenses Against Gradient Inversion

Defenses based on Differential Privacy (Abadi etÂ al., 2016) add noise to the computed gradients on the client side, providing provable privacy guarantees at the cost of significantly reduced utility. Another line of work increases the empirical difficulty of inversion by increasing the effective batch size, by securely aggregating gradients from multiple clients (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2016) or doing multiple gradient update steps locally before sharing an aggregated weight update (Dimitrov etÂ al., 2022). Finally, different heuristic defenses such as gradient pruning (Zhu etÂ al., 2019) have been proposed, although their effectiveness has been questioned (BalunoviÄ‡ etÂ al., 2022b).

Sparsely used Dictionary learning

Recovering the disaggregation matrix ğ‘¸ğ‘¸{\bm{Q}} is related to the well-studied problem of sparsely-used dictionary learning. However, there the aim is to find the sparsest coefficient matrix (corresponding to our âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’â„’ğ’\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}) and dense dictionary (ğ‘¸âˆ’1superscriptğ‘¸1{\bm{Q}}^{-1}) encoding a given signal (ğ‘³ğ‘³{\bm{L}}) up to some error. In contrast, we do not search for the sparsest solution yielding an approximate reconstruction but a solution that exactly induces consistent ğ‘¿ğ‘¿{\bm{X}} and âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’â„’ğ’\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}, which happens to be sparse.

Generally, sparsely-used dictionary learning is known to be NP-hard (Tillmann, 2014) and typically solved approximately (Aharon etÂ al., 2006; Spielman etÂ al., 2012; Sun etÂ al., 2016). However, in specific cases, it can be solved exactly in polynomial time (Spielman etÂ al., 2012). While âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚ğ’â„’ğ’\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} is not sufficiently sparse to satisfy these conditions, we draw inspiration from Spielman etÂ al. (2012) in SectionÂ 4.

8 Limitations

In line with results showing that recovering the order of batch elements is generally impossible for gradient inversion (Geiping etÂ al., 2020; Yin etÂ al., 2021; Geng etÂ al., 2021; Dimitrov etÂ al., 2022), our approach only recovers the input ğ‘¿ğ‘¿{\bm{X}} up to permutation.

Further, we focus on recovering the inputs to fully connected layers such as they occur at the beginning of fully connected networks or as aggregation layers of many other architectures. Extending our approach to other layers is an interesting direction for future work. Similarly, we focus on FedSGD and believe that work on FedAvg is another interesting direction for future work.

Finally, our approach scales exponentially with batch size bğ‘b. While it is practically effective for moderate batch sizes bâ‰²25less-than-or-similar-toğ‘25b\lesssim 25 and can be parallelized to a large degree, much larger batch sizes remain out of reach.

9 Conclusion

We propose SPEAR, the first algorithm permitting batches of b>1ğ‘1b>1 elements to be recovered exactly in the honest-but-curious setting. We show theoretically and empirically that SPEAR succeeds with high probability and experimentally demonstrates that our highly parallelized GPU implementation is effective across a wide range of settings, including batches of up to 242424 elements and large networks and inputs.

We thereby demonstrate that contrary to prior belief, an exact reconstruction of batches is possible in the honest-but-curious setting, suggesting that federated learning on ReLU networks might be inherently more susceptible than previously thought. To still protect client privacy, large effective batch sizes, obtained, e.g., via secure aggregation across a large number of clients, might prove instrumental by making reconstruction computationally intractable.

10 Broader Impact

In this work, we demonstrate that contrary to prior belief, an exact reconstruction of batches is possible in the honest-but-curious setting for federated learning. As our work demonstrates the susceptibility of federated learning systems using ReLU networks, this work inevitably advances the capabilities of an adversary. Nonetheless, we believe this to be an important step in accurately assessing the risks and utilities of federated learning systems.

To still protect client privacy, large effective batch sizes, obtained, e.g., via secure aggregation across a large number of clients, might prove instrumental by making reconstruction computationally intractable. As gradient information and network states can be stored practically indefinitely, our work highlights the importance of proactively protecting client privacy in federated learning not only against current but future attacks. This underlines the importance of related work on provable privacy guarantees obtained via differential privacy.

Appendix C Dataset Licenses

In this work, we use the commonly used MNIST LeCun etÂ al. (2010), CIFAR-10 Krizhevsky etÂ al. (2009) and Tiny-ImageNet Le & Yang (2015) datasets. No information regarding licensing has been provided on their respective websites.

Appendix D Deferred Experiments

D.1 Experiments on Label-Heterogeneous Data

In this section, we provide additional experiments on clients with heterogeneous data. In particular, we look at the extreme case where each client has data only from a single class. As label repetition makes optimization-based attacks harder (Geiping etÂ al., 2020; Yin etÂ al., 2021; Geng etÂ al., 2021), the results presented in TableÂ 2 for the TinyImageNet dataset demonstrate another advantage of our algorithm, namely, SPEAR works regardless of the label distribution, providing even better reconstruction results compared to TableÂ 1 for single-label batches.

D.2 Additional Experiments on Effect of Training on SPEAR

In FigureÂ 7 in the main paper, we provided the results of evaluating SPEAR on a network in training on the same train data used for training. Here, we instead look at what happens if we evaluate the same network in training on fresh data coming from the MNIST test set. The results are presented in FigureÂ 9. We observe similar trends, suggesting that our attack will work equally well on federated clients that already participated in the training, as on those that participate for the first time in later epochs.

D.3 Additional Experiments on Failure Probabilities

In this section, we provide more experiments validating our theoretical analysis of SPEARâ€™s failure rate for several additional batch sizes bğ‘b. We present our results in FigureÂ 10, where we observe similar trends to FigureÂ 8, reaffirming our original results.

Appendix E Visualisations of our results

Here we present a visual comparison between all batch images recovered by our method and Geiping etÂ al. (2020) on TinyImageNet for a 6 layer fully connected network with width m=200ğ‘š200m=200. In FigureÂ 11 we operate in the same setting as SectionÂ D.1, namely batches of a single class. We observe that while some images are well reconstructed by Geiping etÂ al. (2020), most of the images are of poor visual quality, with some even being hard to recognize. In contrast, all of our recovered images are pixel perfect. This in particular also means, that SPEARâ€™s reconstructions improve in fine-detail recovery even upon the well recovered images of Geiping etÂ al. (2020). This is expected as our attack is exact (up numerical errors).

Finally, we demonstrate what happens to our proposed reconstructions in the rare cases when our algorithm fails to recover a batch, i.e., it fails to find or select some of the correct directions qÂ¯isubscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘–\overline{q}_{i}. In FigureÂ 12, we show the one-and-only such batch for the experiment on TinyImageNet presented in TableÂ 1. The batch had 2 wrong qÂ¯isubscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘–\overline{q}_{i}s and still achieves an average PSNR of 91.291.291.2, which is much higher compared to prior work. Further, all but 2 images are affected by the failure.
